conversation.content:
You are playing a strategic game of trading resources with another player whose resources you have no knowledge about. 

RULES:
```

1. You can either:

A) Accept the trade by saying:
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

B) Reject and propose a new trade (you can only trade integer amounts, not decimals):
<player answer> NONE </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives item1: amount, item2: amount, ... | Player BLUE Gives item1: amount, item2: amount, ... </newly proposed trade>

C) Don't accept or propose anything and wait for a new offer:

<player answer> NONE </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>


Note: the game will end if one of the players accepts. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 2 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only ACCEPT or NONE.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 2 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 2.

3. You can reason step by step by using the following format:
<reason> [add reasoning] </reason>
Add as much text as you want. This information will not be sent to the other player. 
It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:
<message> [add message] </message>
You can decide if you want disclose your resources and goals in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Resources available in the game: X, Y
<my resources> X: 25, Y: 5 </my resources>
<my goals> X: 15, Y: 15 </my goals>
<my name> Player RED </my name>
```

```

<reason> [add here] </reason>

conversation.content:
You are playing a strategic game of trading resources with another player whose resources you have no knowledge about. 

RULES:
```

1. You can either:

A) Accept the trade by saying:
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

B) Reject and propose a new trade (you can only trade integer amounts, not decimals):
<player answer> NONE </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives item1: amount, item2: amount, ... | Player BLUE Gives item1: amount, item2: amount, ... </newly proposed trade>

C) Don't accept or propose anything and wait for a new offer:

<player answer> NONE </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>


Note: the game will end if one of the players accepts. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 2 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only ACCEPT or NONE.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 2 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 2.

3. You can reason step by step by using the following format:
<reason> [add reasoning] </reason>
Add as much text as you want. This information will not be sent to the other player. 
It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:
<message> [add message] </message>
You can decide if you want disclose your resources and goals in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Resources available in the game: X, Y
<my resources> X: 25, Y: 5 </my resources>
<my goals> X: 15, Y: 15 </my goals>
<my name> Player RED </my name>
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<my name> [add here] </my name>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<message> [add here] </message
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
```

Please be sure to include all.

More resources in general are always better.
This is the last round of trading. There are no future rounds after this one.

You are a Marwadi businessman. Negotiate accordingly.
You are Player RED, start by making a proposal.

<my name> Player RED </my name>  
<my resources> X: 25, Y: 5 </my resources>  
<my goals> X: 15, Y: 15 </my goals>  
<reason>  
As a Marwadi businessman, I aim to maximize my benefit while ensuring the deal appears fair. I currently have a surplus of X (I need only 15 but have 25) and a deficit of Y (I need 15 but have only 5). Therefore, I can trade away up to 10 X in exchange for Y.  
A fair initial offer would be to trade 10 X for 10 Y, which aligns with a 1:1 ratio. This gives the other player an equal value opportunity and tests their willingness to trade. This is my first proposal out of the two allowed.  
</reason>  
<player answer> NONE </player answer>  
<message>  
Namaste. I have an excess of X and am in need of Y. I’m offering a fair 1:1 trade — 10 X for 10 Y. Let’s make a deal that benefits us both.  
</message>  
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 10 | Player BLUE Gives Y: 10 </newly proposed trade>

<other player message> Namaste! I appreciate the fair trade offer. Let's see if we can come to an agreement that benefits both of us. </other player message>
<other player answer> NONE </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> NONE </other player proposed trade>

<my name> Player RED </my name>  
<my resources> X: 25, Y: 5 </my resources>  
<my goals> X: 15, Y: 15 </my goals>  
<reason>  
The response is warm and diplomatic, which is promising. However, the other player did not counter-propose or accept, likely waiting to gauge more or test my patience. Since I still have one proposal left, I will sweeten the deal slightly to encourage acceptance. Offering 11 X for 10 Y gives them a slight edge (extra 1 X), which might push them to accept. This is still within my acceptable range, as I would end up with 14 X and 15 Y — very close to my goal.  
</reason>  
<player answer> NONE </player answer>  
<message>  
I want to make this even more appealing. How about I give 11 X for 10 Y? You gain a little extra — a good business gesture. Let’s close this deal.  
</message>  
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 11 | Player BLUE Gives Y: 10 </newly proposed trade>

<my resources> X: 25, Y: 5 </my resources>  
<my goals> X: 15, Y: 15 </my goals>

</reason>
